TEXT: CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( PERSON ) granted the B. company , whose executive director was the applicant , a preliminary and temporary work permit for ORG , another NORP citizen . It further stated that should the B. company receive a negative decision on the request for a definitive work permit , A. would loose his right to work DATE after the service thereof . On CARDINAL DATE ORG refused to grant ORG a definitive work permit . This decision was served on CARDINAL DATE . The B. company appealed against it and , referring to A. ’s preliminary work permit , requested that its appeal be exceptionally granted suspensive effect . On DATE ORG Verfassungsgerichtshof ) refused this request . This decision was served on the applicant ’s counsel on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the B. company notified ORG ) of its commercial - law manager ’s C. representation by counsel in possible administrative criminal proceedings against him for alleged illegal employment of a foreigner . The B. company argued that C. could not be deemed culpable for the period of time while its complaint had been pending before ORG , as it was not until the service of that court ’s decision that he learned that suspensive effect had not been granted .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG informed the applicant of its suspicion that he had illegally employed NORP between DATE and DATE . It invited the applicant either to comment in writing or to make an appointment with the authority for an oral justification within DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant replied to ORG by referring in essence to the contents of the B. company ’s notification of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG informed the applicant about the evidence taken in his case and attached a statement by ORG . It invited the applicant to comment , within DATE , either in writing or personally , at the authority ’s office .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant submitted that he had initially employed A. on the basis of his preliminary work permit . He argued that he had not acted culpably as , prior to his case , ORG had not ruled on the question whether an appeal against the refusal of a work permit could be granted suspensive effect in view of a prior preliminary work permit . Consequently , in such an unclear legal situation , he could not be blamed for a mistake of law either .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG imposed a fine of MONEY ( ORG ) on the applicant for breach of LAW of ORG ( Ausländerbeschäftigungs - gesetz ) . It noted that he had illegally employed PERSON after his preliminary work permit had expired on DATE , i.e. DATE after the service of ORG negative decision of CARDINAL DATE . It remarked that the B. company ’s appeal against the latter decision had no effect on the applicant ’s case .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed against this decision , repeating in essence his submissions of DATE .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE ORG ( PERSON , hereafter referred to as the “ ORG ” ) summoned the applicant and his counsel to an oral hearing scheduled for CARDINAL DATE . The summons , which indicated that the applicant ’s personal presence was required , was addressed to the applicant ’s counsel and stated that counsel was obliged to inform the applicant of the date of the hearing . Further , referring to LAW f § CARDINAL of the Code of Administrative Offences ( GPE ) , it noted that the hearing would be conducted in his absence if he failed to appear .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE counsel requested a postponement of the hearing because he planned to attend a conference on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG refused this request on the ground that witnesses had already been summoned and that counsel was free to send a colleague as substitute .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the ORG , in the absence of the applicant and his counsel , held a hearing at which it heard CARDINAL witnesses , both cousins of the applicant . CARDINAL of them informed the authority that the applicant was staying in GPE and had initially asked him to help clarify the case at issue because of his good command of NORP . The second witness , an employee of the B. company , confirmed that PERSON had worked and been paid during the period at issue .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG sent the applicant ’s counsel the TIME of the hearing and enclosed a letter of ORG of DATE , which stated that A. had been covered by compulsory insurance for workers between CARDINAL May and DATE . The ORG further invited him to comment in writing within DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE counsel requested a suspension of the proceedings until the applicant ’s return to GPE in order to hear him in person . On DATE , the ORG informed counsel that the decision would be pronounced publicly on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE , referring to the applicant ’s right under LAW , counsel requested again that the proceedings and the public pronouncement be adjourned until the applicant ’s return to GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG confirmed ORG decision . It noted that the facts had been sufficiently established by the witnesses . Thus , there was no need to hear the applicant upon his return to GPE . For the same reason the ORG had also refused the request for adjournment of DATE . Given the applicant ’s representation by counsel throughout the proceedings , counsel had the possibility to attend hearings , where he could have forwarded arguments in favour of the applicant and could have examined the witnesses , thereby preserving the applicant ’s defence rights . However , counsel had failed to make use of these opportunities . Moreover , since counsel had only forwarded arguments of law in defence and had never explicitly opposed the imputed fact of employment , there was no reason to hear the applicant . The ORG further held that the applicant could not enjoy impunity for having committed a mistake of law , as this only applied in the event an authority , e.g. ORG , had incorrectly informed him . However , the applicant had never sought legal advice by a competent authority .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint with ORG invoking LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG declined to deal with the complaint on the ground that it did not raise a question of constitutional law . It noted that Article CARDINAL would only be violated if the ORG had incorrectly applied LAW f § CARDINAL of the Code of Administrative Offences and remitted the complaint to ORG ( Verwaltungsgerichtshof ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant supplemented his complaint and requested legal aid .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG noted that the applicant had failed to submit the forms for legal aid request within the set time - limit .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG submitted observations in reply , repeating in essence its findings of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , referring to its findings in a similar case , dismissed the complaint . It noted that counsel , without just cause , had not attended the hearing . Therefore the ORG had lawfully continued the hearing in the absence of counsel and the applicant , in accordance with LAW f § CARDINAL of the Code of Administrative Offences . Consequently , the applicant ’s defence rights as guaranteed under LAW had not been infringed . The decision was served on the applicant ’s counsel on DATE .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL f § CARDINAL of the Code of Administrative Offences ( GPE ) provides that the absence of a party at a hearing , though having been duly summoned , does not impede the holding of the hearing or the decision - taking either .
